title: How to Add a Horizontal Line in Microsoft Word: Step-by-Step

steps.title: Click the Insert tab.
steps.content: Click the Insert tab. This tab is in the blue ribbon at the top of the Word window, between Home and Draw .

steps.title: Click Shapes.
steps.content: Click Shapes . It's in the Insert toolbar, next to the icon of an overlapping circle and square. A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Select a line shape.
steps.content: Select a line shape. In the Lines heading, click one of the line templates. You can choose a line, line arrow, double line arrow, and more.

steps.title: Draw your line.
steps.content: Draw your line. Click and drag across the document to create your line. If you need to adjust the line's length and orientation, select the line. Click the left or right circle. Drag it left or right to adjust the length, or drag it up and down to adjust the orientation. To move the line, click and drag it to the desired position.

steps.title: Click the Home tab.
steps.content: Click the Home tab. This tab is in the blue ribbon at the top of the Word window, between File and Insert . You may already be on this tab by default.

steps.title: Click the "Borders" arrow.
steps.content: Click the "Borders" arrow. This is next to the icon of the dotted square with a solid bottom line. A drop-down menu will open.

steps.title: Click Horizontal Line.
steps.content: Click Horizontal Line . This will be towards the bottom, above Draw Table . A horizontal line will be added.

steps.title: Format your line.
steps.content: Format your line. Double-click the line; a dialogue box will appear. To change the line thickness, use the up and down arrow below Height . The higher the number, the thicker the line will be. To change the color, click the color box underneath Color . Select your desired color. Click OK to save and apply your changes. To move the line, double-click and drag it to the desired position.

steps.title: Place your cursor where you want your line to appear.
steps.content: Place your cursor where you want your line to appear. You'll need to be on a blank line, as this won't work if there is text before or after your cursor on the same line. You'll be creating a horizontal line that spans from one edge of your page to the other. The line will stop at your set margins. If you want to make the line span the whole page, you'll need to change your document margins .

steps.title: Type three dashes in a row.
steps.content: Type three dashes in a row. Use your dash key on the number row at the top of your keyboard, or on the numeric pad.

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter to convert the dashes into a line.
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter to convert the dashes into a line. AutoCorrect will automatically create a solid line that will situate itself directly beneath the previous line of text. Note that the line does not occupy the space of a line of text, but instead exists between lines of text.

steps.title: If you don't have AutoCorrect enabled, do the following:
steps.content: If you don't have AutoCorrect enabled, do the following: Click File . Click Options . Click Proofing . Click AutoCorrect Options . Click the AutoFormat As You Type tab. Check the box for Border lines . Click OK . If you want to turn off AutoCorrect , uncheck the boxes.

steps.title: Use different characters for different line styles.
steps.content: Use different characters for different line styles. There are a variety of different lines that you can create by using characters other than the dash: [1] X Research source Thin line : Three hyphens (-). Thick line : Three underscores (_). Double line : Three equal signs (=). Dotted line : Three asterisk (*). Triple line : Three pound signs (#). Squiggly line : Three tildes (~).

steps.title: Move the line by entering text above it.
steps.content: Move the line by entering text above it. You can prompt the line to move down by typing text above it and then pressing Enter . Deleting text above the line will prompt it to move upward.

steps.title: Open a document in the Microsoft Word app.
steps.content: Open a document in the Microsoft Word app. This looks like a blue notebook next to a W . Microsoft Word is available for iOS in the App Store and for Android in the Google Play Store . Tap Blank document to open a new document or tap a file to open an existing document.

steps.title: Tap ••• .
steps.content: Tap ••• . This can be found above the keyboard, to the right. On Android, this may look like an arrow. If you don't see your keyboard, tap the document to bring it up. A new menu will open.

steps.title: Tap Home.
steps.content: Tap Home . This will be to the left of the formatting window. A drop-down menu will open.

steps.title: Tap Insert.
steps.content: Tap Insert . You'll see a list of all objects you can insert.

steps.title: Tap Shapes.
steps.content: Tap Shapes . This is next to the icon of an overlapping circle and square.

steps.title: Select a line shape.
steps.content: Select a line shape. In the "Lines" heading, tap one of the line templates. You can choose a line, line arrow, double line arrow, and more.

steps.title: Draw your line.
steps.content: Draw your line. Tap and drag across the document to create your line. Use two fingers to pinch and zoom out to view the entire document. If you need to adjust the line's length and orientation, tap the left or right circle. Drag it left or right to adjust the length, or drag it up and down to adjust the orientation. To move the line, tap and drag it to the desired position.
